author: LAPhill
content:
Shout out to @Tim O’Sullivan for not only finally solving my hum issues, but dialing in the workflow in my room to a whole other level. He wired up all my pedals, synths, and preamps to a couple of patch bays so I can throw signal all around the room in any order (complete with right-angle cables so I can use them with the desk doors closed). He also built MIDI lines to send clock from my DAW to the pedals and we upgraded the room to Mio MIDI-over-Ethernet units. Several other creature comforts that allow me to think less, like routing a headphone connection underneath the right side of my desk instead of the left where my interface is, adding a second one by the piano, and ready-to-go cables for guitars, synths and microphones already plugged in where they need to be.

I'm going to run out of reasons not to call this studio "done" soon.

author: P.K. Stephan
content:
Hey guys! I am new to the community and happy to have finally taken the jump into the discord after being an avid listener since the beginning.

Just finished building my studio about half a year ago. I run a hybrid setup where everything is always connected and ready to go. All recording paths are accessed via an XLR patch-bay. Mixbus/Mastering gear is controlled by a Dangerous Liaison. Conversion is done via MADI and AES/EBU. Headphone CUE’s are analog and via AVB. I like having everything connected and mic’ed up because I notice that I only use the stuff that I can access quickly while producing/mixing. I went through a lot of trial and error building and working in this studio (been in this location for 1.5 years) so if anyone needs any input I would be happy to help!

author: BatMeckley
content:
Protecting Ruairi.
|| So, interesting enough I had the exact same impression as @chrissorem but came to the totally opposite conclusion. The 420’s are truly fantastic monitors. They do the low end thing that I like out of the PMC 6-2’s without that weird pressed against the glass flatness that I hear in them. A much more pleasant high end too. And their sub information is staggering, especially if you can get some distance from the speakers. But. They do run a bit lean in the 250-500hz range and FOR ME that would cause me to make poor mix decisions. And they really come alive when you’re farther away from them than would be practical in my particular space. For that reason sharks, im out.

The PMC 6’s however blew me away. Leaps and bounds better for me than the 6-2, and I could work on them without a sub even though I’m sure they’d be better with. They present to me the info as I need to hear it, and complement what I get from the ATC’s nicely. They feel very “as the consumer hears it”. Like my AirPods. ||

And so, I think I might be buying a new pair of speakers.

author: chrissorem
content: @JakeTB  @jonmatteson @David Fuller  alright so I have to say I really like the PMC’6s and if I could I would trade my two-two 6’s. They feel more full range overall.  That being said I’m keeping my two two 6’s and the Neumann 420’s are filling the role that I’m looking for, which is a full range cabinet.  The 420’s frequency spectrum feels very top to bottom and very open.  The low end detail is very zoomed in. I definitely can hear more detail. The mid range also feels very detailed and the top end is nice and open but they are as bright as the PMC’s but I don’t feel like I’m missing any information.  After listening to various songs on the 420’s I thought damn these sound nice, and at the same time I thought but is that good? Like how will they respond actually working on them. Will they help my mixes or will they just sound good? So far they have been revealing and translating quite well. I was concerned about the 300-500hz. Feeling a little tucked in when listening to  finished mixes but as I put them to work I felt like they did show that info as well.  I really dig them and will likely buy them. But I think they might be a bit big for a single set of speakers and will still want to work on some  near fields. They definitely show me different things.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Part of what I did today too was put the center of my Sterling desk precisely on the centerline of the room and precisely the same distance from the front wall so I could use it as a reference. Once I got that locked in, I used my Bosch double laser thingy mounted to a tripod to reference to the room centerline and then also cast a horizontal line across the room, across the front of the speaker platform. Since both stands and platforms were now actually level, it was easy to see that the platform of the right speaker stand was slightly out vs. the left. So I had to very gingerly and carefully fuck with the platform to get it lined up. Then fine tuning of leveling with the feet. Then, using the double laser thing at the centerline, I verified the height at the speaker platforms by using that translucent target thing to make sure the cross-line it was casting, hit the target as expected (it did) . I did have to do a bunch of nudging of the right speaker stand to match its position from the right and rear wall to match the left speaker's position, which was a pain int he ass.

Definitely an ordeal and was made much easier with the tools I have. Pretty satisfying seeing identical measurements from the same reference points on either speaker stand.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Final note on the back wall (Ruairi feel free to tell me if I’m wrong). Dividing the space with a wall like that essentially makes the back wall anechoic and uses the “other room” as a chamber to let low end that makes it though bounce around, lose energy, and be refiltered as it renters the room so it doesn’t make it back to listening position. There is much more to it of course. It also catches stray reflections, etc so they don’t make it back to listening.

Keep in mind my room is designed to sound as good as possible in the listening position for mastering so reflections that help it feel fun/good for clients on a sofa aren’t helpful to me! 

Synths are around because I like to continually remind myself how difficult finishing a record is and I find staying connected to playing makes me make much more musical mastering decisions!

author: popaganda.
content: Can I interject and steer the convo in a direction that might help some of the lurkers? I tried to throw ns10s into the mix a few years ago and they really confused me. But I can't deny that my heros made great shit on them. There seem to be 2 common denominators I've seen for ns10 people. Either you came up in big studios and they were always there as a reliable reference and you learned them over time. In this context part of the sound of the ns10 is actually the desk reflection. Or you learned from a mentor who worked on them and picked up all the voodoo tricks that helped make them translate. Anybody who had a real mentor likely understands ns10s because they were ubiquitous to genX and before. I'm trying to understand if there's any use to a 25 year old now who's never been in a big studio or had a mentor and wants to do good work. I was the first to discourage someone from getting them yesterday in monitoring. Was my take wrong?

author: LAPhill
content:
I don't want speaker designers looking at NS-10s and thinking "we need more of THAT!" We have it. It does a thing. It's very useful at that thing. We even have a CLA version of the thing if we want a sillier version of the thing. They're probably less useful than they were in the 80s for many applications (due to the extended low end in all genres of music now). 

I want my speakers designed by people pushing the envelope of what's possible, trying things and looking for ways to overcome past limitations. Trying weird ideas to see what sticks, and go deep on the technical side. I also want them to be music lovers. I think @Gerhard Westphalen is all of these things. I want him thinking this way so that I do not have to.

author: BatMeckley
content: This is why graphs drive me nuts. A speaker is so much more than its response graph. I’m convinced a big part of why they translate the way they do is because of their time domain response and the sealed cabinet ness of it all, but that is an incredibly from the guy uneducated guess. Also, everyone is talking about 26hz but to me SO MUCH of the translation is the nasty 1-3k the ns10 really makes you work on

author: Rob Domos
content: They measure +/- 3db, which means there’s a 6db difference between the most accentuated and most recessed frequencies. 6db is a doubling of amplitude, and IMO this isn’t all that flat.  Those amplitude wiggles being in different places contribute to the differences between genelecs and PMCs. That said, a LOT of other shit contributes to those differences too, and those differences are also quantifiables. Group delay, thd curve, the amount of time it takes for a driver to settle, how defraction, and on and on…. I personally respect the shit out of gerhards work to explore and improve those quantifiable metrics

author: LAPhill
content:
I was chatting with @Nomograph Mastering about this yesterday. For people like Matt, they're working to solve problems on a different tier than most people need to worry about for awhile. It's a deck of cards, and if you start tweaking the angles of your cards on the third level, but your foundation isn't solid, no amount of tweaking is going to fix that and it's still going to fall apart on you. Cian can start to solve his low end integration only after years of having a great room. And he had to get to the point that he had the great room in which the difference between an Unf*ck'd, mismatched pair of subs vs. integrated PMCs was even on his radar of things to worry about. (Putting a lot of words in his mouth now.)

With the Squire thing - there are 1000 variablels and skills to be learned before you reach the ceiling of how far you can get with it. People like to shit on the Apollos here, but we all know plenty of great records were made with them, despite not being "the best" sounding. It's fun to fixate on the minutiae, but it seldom gets to the root of the issue of what's holding you back.

author: cian riordan
content: I think the attack wall solves the problem for people that can't build their room from scratch. As someone that just built a studio, building fake walls with insulation & membranes tucked behind aint cheap. And it's permanent. Having tube traps (or the ASC pressure traps, or whatever they are) are not a panacea -- but rather a scalable, portable method of getting an untreated room in the ballpark. I've found with tube traps that more is not necessarily better and you just don't know till you get in there and shoot it. My friend Andrew Maury raves about his. He's gets amazing results and he loves moving around his setup every few months just because he likes tweaking... and the attack wall allows him to do this. So -- if you're building a studio from the ground up, there are absolutely better options. But if you're hopping around from space to space and don't feel like spending $10-15k on framing, fabric, rockwool, & building limp mass membranes... these are a terrific option.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: That graph says it all. The ns10 thing is just an incorrectly designed crossover (because a proper one would’ve been too expensive). “Tightness” just comes from the lack of bottom end. Yes, because it’s sealed but only in the sense that sealed doesn’t provide extended bottom end. The “transient” benefits of sealed don’t really come through. I spent a lot of time designing a proper crossover for them. It can be done but then they just sound like cheap speakers and their usefulness is gone for someone who’s used to it and relies on the problem

author: BatMeckley
content: Exactly. I think a real argument can be made that something like an ns-10 or an auratone are truly must have speakers for the information they provide. And therefore by definition are not objectively bad.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: But of course you can make mistakes or do things that are just wrong (usually caused by cutting corners to cut cost) which is separate from designing a speakers that certain people like. Plenty of speakers with $1 tweeters which are horribly distorted. It’s a “trade off” the designer made in the sense that they traded subjective and objective performance for cost but it’s not a trade off you’d intentionally make if you’re trying to design a better speaker

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
so OLED is where every pixel is its own backlight, microLED is that but without burn-in (but also like $100k for one), and miniLED is an in between. Essentially it's a QLED (lots of colors and bright af) with a ton of backlight zones/full array local dimming. Essentially it has great color depth and brightness without OLED problems, though it doesn't quite match the pixel response (but is still quite fast) and it's not quite as many backlight zones (since not every single pixel is its own backlight like on OLED and microLED). Hopefully that's not too much word vomit lol

At the end of the day, I have an OLED in the living room and a miniLED as a computer monitor and for everyday use as a monitor this is great. The advantages you'd gain of going with an actual monitor that has DisplayPort are good if your computer doesn't have HDMI 2.1 since you'd then be able to hit 120Hz at 4k and it would feel quite buttery smooth

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
I would be very curious to hear the unfuck guys' chat tube traps! I keep seeing Jon’s in pics and curious to hear his thoughts as well.

They have been great for me. I scored my whole set in 2 batches (16 tubes, 3 speaker stands) for roughly $4500 total - which is still pricey but a great “deal.” Also, they make my Apartment’s basement bedroom usable. 

They lock you into a very specific aesthetic and ergonomic setup, which I have found interesting to navigate (placing a desk, can’t adjust speaker height, etc.).

They also sound great for tracking! I have used them while tracking drums, harp, vocals, and other things with excellent results.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Yes, for sure! As a renter, work-from-home option, they are a dream. I think you could get better ergonomics and potentially better sound from other studio design options, but the flexibility is great. They are definitely not a magic bullet to get a “flat room” either and placement / quantity can affect things greatly. 

Andrew Maury was the one who inspired my initial purchase! He does fantastic work on them and was definitely a great resource as I was looking into them. He shared this video with Greg from Kush audio which was very convincing at the time  https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=P7pOA4eeuS0&t=72m13s

I also have friends who have had good success building diy tube traps — which can be pretty affordable.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Hey 👋 

So honestly, I don’t have further bass trapping (and I should). I have the 16 9” tube traps and 3 13” speaker stand tube traps (that probably do dip a bit lower into the bass trapping realm), then I have a 4’ x 2’ x 4” cloud above me from ATC. Then just two wall-mounted ATC panels in the back. 

My room has a bump at 85 Hz, but I have mostly learned to work around that! It’s not a big issue outside of some sustained bass notes.

author: Maxim
content:
I’d wholeheartedly recommend the Focal Clear MG. Out of the box they were my favorite in the 1-1.5k price range. I tested the HEDDs, Airpod Max, Audeze LCD-X and own the M50s and HD650s. 

I was looking for the headphone that gave me the best assortment of detail, fun, space, and „translation“ to speakers out of the box (without extra eq or another amp to power it outside of my UAD interface). 

For my taste the Focals fit that perfectly. Even hooked up to my laptop directly the sound was extremely fun, detailed and useful in making decisions. 

Also the look, comfort, travel case and extra pads are a nice touch. Only negative for me was the cable being a bit too short in a recording/moving around in a studio setting. But I wouldn’t use them for that anyways. 

AirPod Max (with noise canceling) would probably be second. They just lack the finer details and deep bass for me. 

Then the LCD-x (they are technically better than the Airpods but I wouldn’t prefer the LCDs in a real world setting. Only in the studio with some eq added).

HEDDs I so heavily disliked it wasn’t even funny. The UAD Interface can’t power them properly and they just sounded like a crappy and weird set of nearfield speakers playing from either side of your ear. Can’t even explain it.

For referencing I use regular AirPods and my iPhone speaker. But at least now I know if for some reason I decide to go mobile in the near future the Focals will be my first choice.

author: cian riordan
content:
So here’s the roundup on my dumb drum thing. This is a scrappy little experiment on my part to see if I can get a convincing drum sound in my little drum room. Before starting this, I had the idea in my mind that if a room is good for mixing, it must be good for recording! *Insert Game Show Buzzer* I ran into many of the things I didn’t like about the Barefoot Studio B Live room — and those things were exaggerated by a factor of 10. First of all, my room is very dead by design. It treats me great in mixing, but made for a real challenge when trying to get *some* sort of drum personality. I was also working with a pretty shitty old premier kit that hadn’t seen the light of day in half a decade. Shitty cymbals, very quickly tuned heads — I wasn’t setting myself up for success… but whatever.

The setup was a little ridiculous (minus a few utilitarian pieces):
Kick: Beta 52 -> Scully 280
Snare: SM57 -> Scully 280
OH Mono: Coles 4038 -> Ampex 351 -> 1176 (not compressing, just to trim gain before ‘tools)
OH L/R: U67s -> UTA pre (thanks Matt!)
Kick Room: U47 -> UTA Pre (again…)

This is where I ended up, without mixing, and with some quick playing and utility EQ/balancing. No compression except a limiter to bring up the level. While the actual drums themselves don’t sound amazing, I really struggled with getting any sort of energy out of the drums… it all just got sucked out. 

Here are the results if you care (don’t judge my shitty playing)

I think if it do this again I would:
1) Have a better sounding kit. Turns out, shit in.. shit out. I knew this. We all know this. But here I am.
2) Maybe put some sheets of plywood around to create some surface in the room. Just give it some life.
3) Not use the Scully. It’s so hard to get them to not sound distorty… I just don’t have enough pres on hand to have clean path for everything. Mix studio living.

So it goes…

content: I’ve done it a couple ways. Most aggressive is to patch the output of the mixer back into one of the mixer channels, then use that to drive it. Or you can just crank the main output of the whole synth, which is what I did.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Unplug the tweeter on some speakers and put it up against some PMCs. Same thing

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Good luck convincing anyone NS10s are objectively good speakers. NS10s were never released as some bizarre speaker for mixing on. They’re bookshelves for home use. Try convincing anyone they’re the right choice for your home stereo

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: So a speaker with no tweeter is objectively good if I work on them and win a Grammy

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Something that’s broken I’d consider objectively bad without really needing a certain threshold. Woofers don’t really meet the tweeters. It can be done but takes a lot of parts and costs $100 for the crossover alone. They decided to put in a crossover which doesn’t remotely resemble a “proper” crossover so you get that giant peak. It’s not an intentional design choice or something they wanted. It was “oh crap, we can’t get this design to work and don’t have the budget to make a finished product” and releasing it anyways

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: In the same sense that a speaker with no tweeter is only broken in my opinion

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I never said it was the frequency response that is to blame for this. I just said the frequency response is representative of the problems there. If you EQ a speaker to match that it won’t sound like an NS10 cause you won’t have all of the problems from their crossover

author: Rollmottle
content: do NS-10's have a smooth frequency response?

author: BatMeckley
content:
Up to a point. Just because a carrot is part of a stew doesn’t mean a stew is a carrot.

Atc’s don’t have ruler flat response and are hyper useful. I think part of this is that frequency response is WAY overhyped and doesn’t tell nearly as much about a speaker as people want it too pmc and genelec can both measure flat and sound ENTIRELY different. So much in the time domain and presentation and thd doesn’t show up on a graph like that. And that’s the point.

And for someone who’s trying to sell speakers to imply that is, or that NS10s are broken or objectively bad deserves all the pushback they’re getting

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: You could make a flat speaker that’s completely unusable (let’s have the tweeter fire in the other direction, put a wall between you and the speaker…) so I don’t really care to look at frequency responses other than for revealing specific problems that you know via other sources like the NS10 crossover

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is peak internet message board: decades of experience and usefulness, millions of songs made, for decades almost every hit touched an ns10 at one point or another. Literally multiple of the most famous mixers of all time insist they be in every room they mix in. And then one person that sells a competing speaker goes “they suck!” And everyone goes “let’s hear him out!”

The irony is, i hate ns10’s, but the best translating mixes I’ve ever done were on them. I don’t like kale salad, but it’s good for me.

author: jmlongmusic
content:
Hey everyone! I’m new to the community - really enjoying it so far. This will be a long post asking for some studio build advice — I hope that’s ok. Please just let me know if there’s a better thread for this sort of thing. 

I’d be extremely grateful for any feedback! Here’s some info: 

- I am currently moving my home studio to this basement space that is about 400 SQ feet. Concrete floor and walls except for the front wall shown in this picture - that is drywall as it separates the rest of the basement. 

- The ceiling joists are exposed and are about 7.5” deep. 

- My primary function for this room will be mixing, but I will also be doing smaller overdubs like piano and vocals. 

Currently, after painting the walls and floor, my plan is as follows: 
- Stuff the ceiling joists with insulation — probably Safe N Sound… thoughts on that choice? 

- Cover the joists with fabric from Gilford of Maine. 

- Figure out how to drill into concrete 😂 Then put panels everywhere. Most of my panels are about 4” thick and are comprised of the safe n sound insulation. 
- Put some big rugs down but also leave a bit of the concrete exposed if possible cuz I like the look. Haha 

- My monitoring set up is NS10M’s (don’t laugh) with an Avantone CLA-100 amp and a PreSonus T10 sub. I’ve got an Apollo 8 Duo and Apollo Twin X Quad. 

That concludes my plan so far. Am I on the right track? 😳 

I really appreciate any feedback you’re willing to give. 🙏

author: Rollmottle
content:
@cian riordan So...I decided to use the left speaker as my reference because when I shot a laser across the speaker platform, it was pretty close to level. So I marked its position on the floor, took the speakers off the stands and then replaced the spikes on the Sound Anchors with some heavier duty feet I found on Amazon. My studio is on a concrete slab so the spikes were always SUCH a pain in the ass to position. New ones have felted bottoms and are way easier to maneuver. 

Once I got my new feet on each of the stands, I used my nifty new digital level to tune the stands to be exactly level by leveling out their feet. Then, I tuned the speaker platforms to be exactly level now that the stands themselves were level. This was a pain in the ass. Lot of light touch, some mallet, and lots of cursing. My Bosch laser measurer came in very handy to measure the height from the bottom of the speaker stand to the floor on either side. Makes it way easier to get them exact.

author: Rollmottle
content: yes...self-leveling and repeatable height would be clutch in a speaker stand. even my slab seems to be 1 degree out of square from left to right.

author: itMIGHTbeNICK
content:
This is my humble home setup in the corner of my bedroom. There’s nothing glamorous here. While I’m still building out the room downstairs and things have been at a hault due to some financial difficulties I won’t get into. I’m doing most of my work right here these days if I can’t get studio time at my buddys space. I’m incredibly proud of the mixes and masters I’ve been able to do in this little corner. I set up some gobos and tube traps I have in the closet when I’m getting deep into the mix and it’s all been working out as best as it can for the situation at hand.
NS10’s have the cap mod. 

When I need to track my guitar amps I completely isolate them with long cables and treatment directly in my closet or I will close off the bathroom and treat them in there as well as capture the natural reflection in our bathroom. My wife and kids are so incredibly sensitive and generous to me during this time to even let me still be able to work and make this happen while the studio build is on hold and we’re having to make things work.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Keep in mind speakers can get damaged even if you don't see it. I shouldn't mention any specifics but I once had a speaker shipped with pretty decent packaging (double boxed, foam etc) which UPS managed to drop so hard the woofer's motor tore entirely off. It wasn't even some cheap stamped frame. High end pretty heavy duty (metal) frame. Yours might not get damaged to that extreme but could get cracked and have problems later on. Shipping speakers that are large enough to have real weight to them but not heavy enough that you need a pallet is risky business. Almost guaranteed to get tossed off a truck

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Lots of great ideas here! I'm personally on the @Rollmottle train (also @cian riordan aesthetic is similarish)...I just agree aesthetically that I like the brighter/cleaner/warmer vibe. Of course your tastes may differ, but my lights dim like @montrose recording  said...it's really nice when it's getting later in the day to have some more dim lighting to match the outside a bit. 

Also really love to keep things ultra simple visually...the least amout of things around (even cords, etc) but again that's just me. Different things inspire us all.

Also big fan of keeping the digital environment very organized, as few things open as I need. I still certainly can get distracted like the rest of us. One thing I underestimated about running a full time mastering shop is just the number of interactions per day that are needed...and that can definitely take you out of the flow so I tend to keep it very contained...say only respond at certain points of the day and generally I deliver all my files at the end of the day in one batch. I'm sure some similar type of thing can be achieved for us all no matter the process. Still a work in progress over here of course!

My final thought is that the best focus enabler I've found is just good old fashioned hard-nosed exercise. Getting up early, squatting heavy, hard sprints...taking things to the limit (safely) really allow me personally to retain a very real sense of resilience and focus. And increase and double-down on discipline -- which in turn increases motivation often for me!

Best of luck! As far as I can tell, retaining focus in our current age is an eternally ongoing (and extremely valuable) skill to work on

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yup! They're very similar in that regard, but still different. You can generally think of RM as the fast version of tremolo (volume modulation), in the way that FM synthesis is the fast version of vibrato (pitch modulation). Both techniques generate side bands through modulation rates that are in the audible range (> 20 Hz).

The difference between RM and tremolo is that tremolo is a uni-polar modulation and ring modulation is bipolar, which will generate different side bands. I'm a little fuzzy on the math of it these days, but if I remember correctly RM will generate negative side bands which are reflected at 0 Hz and start to travel back up the spectrum, whereas with AM they disappear when they get to 0 Hz.

Pop 'em in a frequency analyzer and watch the side bands go! Especially the RM. It's pretty informative.
